title: merge() doesn't throw any Error when source object is frozen
body:
### Description
I'm calling **merge()** on a frozen object.
```js
const frozen = Object.freeze({ a: "1" });
merge(frozen, { a: "2", b: "123" });
```

### Expected behavior
I would expect **merge()** to throw an **Error** in this case.

### Actual behaviour
**merge()** silently completes leaving the destination object without change.

Codesadbox illustrating the issue: https://codesandbox.io/s/lodash-merge-frozen-hos4h?file=/src/index.js.

title: cloneDeep gets longer and longer
body:
I have a component which display list of elements, which can be filtered.
Every time a filter is applied, I have to cloneDeep the list of elements.
Problem is that cloneDeeps is taking longer and longer to process.

I use cloneDeep this way : 
```
import cloneDeep from 'lodash/cloneDeep';
...
this.copyRows = cloneDeep(this.rows); 
...
this.flattenedRows = cloneDeep(this.displayedRows);
```

I've added some console.log() that show that time is approximately x2 each time I apply a new filter.
If I navigate outside the page, and then come back on this page, 1st filter takes normal time, and then increase every time that we ask for a new filter.
NB : It's not about the filter that I used, I've tried with a boolean filter and switch it to true/false many time, and every time the cloneDeep processing time increase.

Is there any cache or something I can force clean?
Many thx

title: Inconsistent _.rearg behavior

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This is a bug report.

From the [rearg docs](https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#rearg):
> Creates a function that invokes func with arguments arranged according to the specified indexes where the argument value at the first index is provided as the first argument, the argument value at the second index is provided as the second argument, and so on.

What's the issue?
`rearg` is not mapping arguments as expected when the number of input arguments is less than the arity of the wrapped function.

Example:
```
var rearged = _.rearg(function(a, b) {
  return [a, b];
}, [0, 0]);
```

Call: `rearged('b');`
Expected result: `[ 'b', 'b' ]`
Actual result: `[ 'b', undefined ]`

When the function is called with a second argument, the actual result is the expected one:

Call: `rearged('b', 'foo');`
Result: `[ 'b', 'b' ]`

Please let me know if this is expected behavior or an actual bug. I'm willing to work on a fix.

`this.onPressDebounced = _.debounce((...params) => this.onPressed(...params), 500 , {

This is a duplicate of #4008

title: Debounced function not awaiting async function

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
##Example project

https://github.com/chrissyast/band-repertoire/tree/api-call-in-separate-file-await-in-component

##Steps to reproduce

1. Type a few letters in the search field and wait
1. Type a few more letters or delete some

##Expected outcome 

After step 1: Search results matching search field at step 1 are shown
After step 2: Search results matching search field at step 2 are shown

##Actual outcome

After step 1: No search results
After step 2: Search results matching the text that was in the search field at **step 1** are shown

It seems that the debounced function is not successfully awaiting the result 

```
    delayedLastFmQuery = _.debounce(async function (q) {
       var delayedResponse = await sendLastFmQuery(q)
        return delayedResponse
    }, 500);
```

I saw on a [stack overflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50837291/how-to-use-debounce-on-async-function#comment105742167_50837389) that async functions with lodash debounce only work when `leading` is set to `true` but this fires off a search on the first letter being entered which is not ideal behaviour for me

title: Bug: sortBy and orderBy fail on (string | number) arrays
body:
For all-string or all-number arrays, lodash matches `Array.sort`:
```js
['b', 'a' ,'c'].sort()
// ['a', 'b', 'c']

_.sortBy(['b', 'a' ,'c'])
// ['a', 'b', 'c']
```

But for mixed arrays, it returns an unsorted result:
```js
['b', 1 ,'c'].sort()
// [1, 'b', 'c']


_.sortBy(['b', 1 ,'c'])
// ['b', 1 ,'c']
```

title: Escape the character '-' in _.escapeRegExp.js

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body: This pull request makes _.escapeRegExp to also escape `-`, the RegExp range character. More information about this in the issue https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4807

title: _.escapeRegExp does not escape '-'
body:
The character '-' determines ranges of characters in regexp. 
Not escaping it can generate some regexp to fail when including escaped characters, since it can make RegExp think that it's representing a range.
Example given:
```
const allowedChars = _.escapeRegExp('+-=');
const wrongRegex = new RegExp(`^[${allowedChars}]*$`);
console.log('0'.match(wrongRegex)); // Should not match, but it does, because 0 is between + and =
console.log('0'.match(new RegExp(/^[\+\-=]$/))); // expected escaping, no match
```

title: reject(arrayOfVals, val) unexpected behavior
body:
so was expecting reject to remove any value I plug in via shorthand but apparently this is not the case and requires an iterator function to work as expected. Any possibility this could become an acceptable usage?

```
// expected
reject([1, 2, 3], 2)
[1, 3]

reject(['a', 'b', 'c'], 'b')
['a', 'c']

// actual
reject([1, 2, 3], 2)
[1, 2, 3]

reject(['a', 'b', 'c'], 'b')
['a', 'b', 'c']

// works with iterator
reject([1, 2, 3], val => val === 2)
[1, 3]

reject(['a', 'b', 'c'], val => val === 'b')
['a', 'c']

```

title: How to use lodash-es using import in Node 14?
body:
I'm trying to use `lodash-es` in the latest Node 14, which has out of the box support for ES modules 🎉. This means it we do not need any transformation steps in order to load ES modules in a plain node.js application. 

When I create the following test file `test.js`:

```js
// test.js
import { first } from 'lodash-es'

console.log(first([1, 2, 3])) // should print 1
```
And then run it using Node 14:
```bash
$ node test.js
```
It does not work but gives the following error:
```
$ node test.js
file:///.../test.js:1
import { first } from 'lodash-es'
         ^^^^^
SyntaxError: The requested module 'lodash-es' is expected to be of type CommonJS, which does not support named exports. CommonJS modules can be imported by importing the default export.
```
This is because node.js treats the files in `lodash-es` as CommonJS instead of ES6 modules. To solve this, `lodash-es` must somehow explain to node.js that it's containing modules, which as far as I know can be done in two ways ([see nodejs docs](https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#esm_enabling)):

- Add the field `"type": "module"` in `package.json`. I tested this and this works. However, in the past there was an issue with this field, see https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4359, so I'm not sure if we can just do that.
- Give all the files an extension `*.mjs` instead of `*.js`.

title: Feature request: add 3rd param to join for "between last items"

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
It would be nice to have a string parameter to pass to join that would dictate the separator for the final two items. Similar to [twig's join filter](https://twig.symfony.com/doc/3.x/filters/join.html).

Example:
```javascript
_.join(["Fred", "Barney", "Wilma", "Betty"], ", " , " and "); // "Fred, Barney, Wilma and Betty"
_.join(["Fred", "Barney"], ", " , " and "); // "Fred and Barney"
```

Apologies if this has been raised with before I couldn't find any reference when searching the issues. (I also couldn't find join.js in the repo any more!)

title: Simplify isPlainObject

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Recently I'm learning how to write a `isPlainObject` function, and find following codes really confusing:
```js
  let proto = value
  while (Object.getPrototypeOf(proto) !== null) {
    proto = Object.getPrototypeOf(proto)
  }
  return Object.getPrototypeOf(value) === proto
```

As mentioned in feature explanation:
> check if `value` is an object created by **`Object` constructor or one with a `[[Prototype]]` of `null`**

Why we have to "while loop" the  `Object.getPrototypeOf(proto) `, it equals with:
```js
const proto = Object.getPrototypeOf(value)
return proto === null || Object.getPrototypeOf(proto) === null
```
So I propose this update or just make a suggestion to make codes more simplified and understandable.

title: cloneDeep does not clone/remove deep functions but keeps references

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hi, I found this discussion #3558
But it's closed with an incorrect final decision.
Here is a doc for cloneDeep:
> This method is like _.clone except that it recursively clones value.

So I expect not only cloned object itself will be not a reference to the source,
but all the nested deep values will be also cloned.

But in case of deep function values, it's not true, deeply cloned functions are references to their respective originals in the source object

According to this decision:
> The main sticking point is the return value be a clone or value that isn't === to the one provided, not necessarily the properties of the value.

there is no guaranteed difference between clone and cloneDeep.

title: The proposal of add '_.until' function
body:
Sometimes, we would need to call a function more than once to get or generate our expected value. That functions have side-effects that such as changing by the time, API calls or full of randomized values. In this case, we should wrap our function with another function. This wrap functions should call our actual function until return the value on our expecting way. In examples that will you see in the below, we call that reference function as the barrier function.

## Sketch
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3244438/81487496-1089b080-9266-11ea-99d6-c16cc2528115.png)

## Syntax:
```js
_.until(actualFunction, [...arguments], barrierFunction, {retry: Number}?);
```

## Glossary:

- **The actual function**  is the function that could we want to call it more than once.
- **Arguments**: The arguments array exists for the pass to data to our actual function.
- **The barrier function** is the reference function to stop the iteration and return the last generated value. That function should return boolean values. If it returns true the iteration will break and `._until` the function should return the last value of the actual function.
- **options**: There is just one option argument on my mind at the moment. The `retry` value defines the maximum iteration count of the `._until` function. If we can't find the expected value (based to the barrier function) before exceed the retry number, we should the last returned value immediately. This saves us to enter endless loops.

## Examples

### Example 1
```js
const randomizedNumber = _.until(_.random, [1, 5], (number) => number % 2);
```
In this example, `randomizedNumber` variable is absolutely even number. The `._until` function will iterate the actual function until the barrier broke.

### Example 2
```js
const randomizedNumber = _.until(_.random, [1, 5], (number) => number % 2, {retry: 3});
```
In this example, `randomizedNumber` variable could be even or odd number. The `._until` function will iterate 3 times maximum then return the last value without test the data with barrier function.

title: Naming of 'Last' vs 'Right'

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I understand all "regular" functions, but for the reverse function you use "Last" and "Right" - and I do not see a consistency. 

* drop -> dropRight
* dropWhile -> dropRightWhile
* findIndex -> findLastIndex
* indexOf -> lastIndexOf 

See also the confusion between 'last' (whose 'reverse' is 'head' while 'first' is deprecated) and 'lastIndexOf' (which should be 'firstIndexOf' if using the same grammar rules). 

So here is proposal to create new pairs

* drop/dropReverse
* dropWhile/dropWhileReverse
* findIndex/findIndexReverse
* indexOf/indexOfReverse

and there is new ones that can come up
* nth/nthReverse

or you keep the names and alias them in a subfield:

```
_.r = {}
_.r.dropWhile = _.dropRightWhile;
_.r.drop = _.dropRight;
_.r.indexOf = _.lastIndexOf;
// and similar
```
The 'r' could be read as 'right' or 'reverse'. I couldn't find a valid symbol that can be used instead of 'r'

PS what is the reverse operation of 'initial'?

title: `Math.random()` doesn't reliably contain enough state bits to work for shuffling all but very small arrays
body:
The Fisher-Yates shuffle algorithm [can only generate all the permutations of an array provided there's enough bits in the RNG's state to represent the number of all possible permutations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle#Pseudorandom_generators). In small lists (20 or fewer), this rarely matters, but in even medium-size arrays, this presents a problem:

- [V8](https://v8.dev/blog/math-random),[SpiderMonkey](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=322529), [ChakraCore](https://github.com/microsoft/ChakraCore/blob/c97139d2fa291b2bce34fbd21c421bb94f3dc79f/lib/Runtime/Math/JavascriptMath.cpp#L1305-L1315), and [JSC](https://trac.webkit.org/browser/webkit/trunk/Source/WTF/wtf/WeakRandom.h#L91) all use [XorShift128+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xorshift#xorshift+) (128-bit state), can only shuffle lists of up to 34 entries
	- WebKit doesn't make it explicit via comments, but it's pretty obvious when you compare the algorithms that it's 100% identical to Wikipedia's version.
- GraalJS [delegates to Java's `SplittableRandom`](https://github.com/graalvm/graaljs/blob/f4b20be6bda0534030b8eb541f5e8605cda3611c/graal-js/src/com.oracle.truffle.js/src/com/oracle/truffle/js/runtime/JSRealm.java#L2094), and [Java just increments a 64-bit seed by the golden ratio and applies a non-cryptographic hash](https://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk/jdk/file/372d79aca24a/src/java.base/share/classes/java/util/SplittableRandom.java), so it can only reliably shuffle lists of up to 20 entries.
- [Rhino](https://github.com/mozilla/rhino/blob/47c9fe849ff0f8d766abc8a1a919c13a05bfab9a/src/org/mozilla/javascript/NativeMath.java#L291) and [Nashorn (deprecated as of JDK 11)](https://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk/jdk14/file/6c954123ee8d/src/jdk.scripting.nashorn/share/classes/jdk/nashorn/internal/objects/NativeMath.java#l625) both delegate to Java's native `Math.random()`, which [only uses 48 bits of state](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/14/docs/api/java.base/java/util/Random.html) and so can only support shuffling lists of up to 16 entries before some permutations get missed.
- I ignored engines like XS targeting low-resource embedded as Lodash is unlikely to ever be used there.

Of course, you could go with a heavy-weight Mersenne Twister, but in any case, I don't think it's safe to rely on the runtime's native RNG for shuffling.

Array swap function proposal
body:
I am proposing this simple function to swap elements in an array. Although this is trivial, it saves time.

```
/**
 * Swap two elements in an array
 *
 * @since 4.17.15
 * @category Array
 * @param {array} The array where the elements would be swapped.
 * @param {indexA} The index of the first element.
 * @param {indexB} The index of the second element.
 * @example
 *
 * swap([['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'], 0, 1)
 * // => (['b', 'a', 'c', 'd'])
 */
function swap(array, indexA, indexB) {
    let tmp = array[indexA];
    array[indexA] = array[indexB];
    array[indexB] = tmp;
}

export default swap

title: _.conforms: cannot validate missing properties

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This is the same issue as https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/2262 which is closed and locked by bot for inactivity.

Currently

```JavaScript
_.conforms({ foo: _.isEmpty })({ bar: '' })
```

returns `false`, for property `foo` does not exists on source. This is highly counter intuitive and prevents many use-cases.

title: Update docs for `_.intersectionWith` comparator to avoid confusion regarding comparator argments

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I just ran into the same issue as here: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/2798

It current says "The comparator is invoked with two arguments: (arrVal, othVal).". I assumed that `arrVal` was the first array, and `othVal` would always be one of the other arrays.

When you read "The order and references of result values are determined by the first array", it also makes you think that `arrVal` is always the first array.

Also the signature is written as:

```
_.intersectionWith(objects, others, _.isEqual);
```

It should be made clear that the params of the comparator can be either `objects` or any of the `others` arrays.

title: add bounds function #4711
body:
Address #4711 

- The `bounds` function  sorts an array of elements and returns the minimum and maximum values.
- If the passed array is empty, an empty array is returned.

```javascript
 bounds([200, 100, 250, 150])
 // => [100, 250]
 
 bounds(['beaver', 'alpaca', 'zebra', 'duck'])
 // => ['alpaca', 'zebra']
 
```

title: `lodash/chain` not including prototype functions
body:
I noticed this in a project I'm working on. We do `import chain from 'lodash/chain';` and we have webpack alias `lodash` to `lodash-es`. But when we run our Jest unit tests, we get and error that `chain(...).groupBy is not a function`

Not sure why, so I loaded up the node REPL and discovered this:

```
> $ node
Welcome to Node.js v12.13.1.
Type ".help" for more information.
> var lodash = require('lodash');
undefined
> lodash.chain([]).groupBy
[Function]
> var { chain } = require('lodash');
undefined
> chain([]).groupBy
[Function]
> var chainDirect = require('lodash/chain');
undefined
> chainDirect([]).groupBy
undefined
>
```

seems `var chain = require('lodash/chain');` is broken as you don't get any of the methods on the return object from `chain()`, but you do if you `require('lodash')`

node v 12.13.1
lodash v 4.17.15

title: Math method to find both min and max values of array in one pass
cloneDeep doesn't seem to clone deep enough?
body:
This is the behaviour I'm seeing in the repl on your docs site:

```
var a = ['a']
var b = ['b']
var c = [a, b]
var d = [c, c]
var e = _.cloneDeep(d)

console.log(e[0][0], e[1][0])
console.log(e[0][0] === e[1][0]) // true, expected false
```

Here is the runkit:

https://runkit.com/variousauthors/5e83541a23e1a60014faeb6c

Is this expected behaviour? I thought none of the references would be equal...

Maybe we need to `_.cloneDeeper` :D

title: Unable to build a CSP compliant version of isEqual
body:
I have tried to build a CSP compliant version of the `isEqual` but in line 100, there is the following code:
```
var root = freeGlobal || freeSelf || Function('return this')();
```

Which uses the non CSP compliant `Function()`.

Here is how I built it using lodash-cli: `lodash include=isEqual`. Commenting out the `Function('return this')()` returns undefined for everything.

title: camelCase & snakeCase
body:
``` javascript
_.camelCase('x_y_z') => 'xYZ'
_.snakeCase('xYZ') => 'x_yz' // confusing

_.camelCase('x_yz') => 'xYz'
```

I think the above snakeCase's results are a bit confusing, what do you guys think, is this a bug or normal behavior.
